comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content: Tragic Shortis Family Events 1901 Census Shows William Shortis as head of the family together with Annie his wife, both 32 years. The Census of 1911 sees them replaced by Nora and Mary Brown sisters and Aunts to the Shortis children. Annie Died in Childbirth 1905 (June 1st) William Shortis, Born: 1869, From Carrick on Suir, Co Tipperary, Married to Annie Browne Died: 1905 (Nov 12th), 'Died of 'Broken heart', leaving 5 children with no parents. Occupation: Manager of Lartige railway. Exported Cashen salmon to Harrods in London, England. Reference: He built Shorti's bar and lodge in Ballybunnion, Co Kerry In 1911 Patrick Was at All Hallows Drumcondra as per the census. Patrick Shortis and Daniel Scanlon both lost their lives in the fight for independence and were honoured by the North Kerry branch of Republican Sinn Fein. Patrick Shortis fought at the GPO in 1916 and was killed with the O'Rahilly on an assault on the Rotunda while Daniel Scanlon lost his life in Ballybunion in 1917 while on active duty against occupied forces. From www.findagrave.com Street View

comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content: Shortis Patrick Irish Vlunteers, Killed in Action, was a Volunteer with the Second Battalion F Company Irish Volunteers. He was aged 23 and was killed on Moor Street on the 28th of April 1916. At 18 years of age he was studying for the priesthood at All-Hallows College, Drumcondra which specialized in training priests for the missions, All-Hollows sent many missionaries to Australia. I have found no records to indicate he finished his training and he is not recorded by the Irish Republican Causalities Committee as being a priest when he died. From irishmedals.org/gpage41.html Patrick Shortis, Ballybunnion, County Kerry, was 26 years (This is Incorrect he was 23 DannyM8) of age and a native ofBallybunion. Took B.A. Degree in National University. Passed Wireless Examination in London, but did not get certificates owing to his views on Ireland. He remained in London, where he was an active member of the Volunteers. He returned to Dublin a few months before the Rising. He was killed in action near the G.P.O. on 28th April. He is buried in the 1916 Plot in St Paul’s, Glasnevin From National Graves Association

comment.author: 56225952@N06
comment._content: Yet another wonderful window into the past. I remember shops like this owned by people who knew the trade inside out, though without the bar, in Loughborough where I was born. Sadly they are nearly all gone now and replaced by faceless, characterless supermarkets or megastores full of disinterested staff. Thank you for this post.

comment.author: 58639088@N05
comment._content: There's something very clean, almost modern, about this self-contained building. It's confident, yet understated, style; the uniformly open windows, the neat bundles of wares; the fine day. All captured in subtle monochrome tones. Wonderful photograph!

comment.author: 68172694@N05
comment._content: There was also a Dr.Liam Shortis from Ballybunion was in Tintown during the Civil war as a Republican prisoner, hes mentioned in Mossie Harnetts book called "Victory & Woe" page 156, he was a brother of Patrick Shortis, he was released in 1924 became a eye specialist and passed away in the 50s.

comment._content: Strange the things you find when you goolge your own name. I'm William Shortis, 51, living in Wellington New Zealand after emigrating when I was 6. For me the shop and bar could only be made better if it backed on to the Shortis brewery. But I guess you can't have everything.
